extension.searchTitle: RECESS; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 30
AFTER RECESS; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 30
FRAUDULENT JOINDER PREVENTION ACT OF 2016; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 30

congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 3624, to amend title 28, United States Code, to prevent fraudulent joinder, by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 189 noes, Roll No. 89.<P/>Rejected the Watson Coleman motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with amendments, by a recorded vote of 180 ayes to 239 noes, Roll No. 88.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on the Judiciary now printed in the bill shall be �D174�considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Buck amendment (No. 1 printed in H. Rept. 114-428) that makes technical changes to the bill; striking references to multiple defendants and replacing them with references to single defendants.<P/>Cartwright amendment (No. 2 printed in H. Rept. 114-428) that sought to create a separate exception for plaintiffs seeking compensation resulting from the bad faith of an insurer (by a recorded vote of 178 ayes to 237 noes, Roll No. 87).

The House passed H.R. 3624, to amend title 28, United States Code, to prevent fraudulent joinder, by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 189 noes, Roll No. 89.<P/>Rejected the Watson Coleman motion to recommit the bill to the Committee on the Judiciary with instructions to report the same back to the House forthwith with amendments, by a recorded vote of 180 ayes to 239 noes, Roll No. 88.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on the Judiciary now printed in the bill shall be �D174�considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule.<P/>Buck amendment (No. 1 printed in H. Rept. 114-428) that makes technical changes to the bill; striking references to multiple defendants and replacing them with references to single defendants.<P/>Cartwright amendment (No. 2 printed in H. Rept. 114-428) that sought to create a separate exception for plaintiffs seeking compensation resulting from the bad faith of an insurer (by a recorded vote of 178 ayes to 237 noes, Roll No. 87).

congVote.result: So the motion to recommit was rejected.

congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 3624, to amend title 28, United States Code, to prevent fraudulent joinder, by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 189 noes, Roll No. 89.
The House passed H.R. 3624, to amend title 28, United States Code, to prevent fraudulent joinder, by a recorded vote of 229 ayes to 189 noes, Roll No. 89.

titleInfo.title: United States House Amendment Number 2 (114th Congress)
United States House Amendment Number 2 (114th Congress)
United States House Amendment Number 2 (114th Congress)
PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 2406, SPORTSMEN'S HERITAGE AND RECREATIONAL ENHANCEMENT ACT OF 2015

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 2406, SPORTSMEN'S HERITAGE AND RECREATIONAL ENHANCEMENT ACT OF 2015; Congressional Record Vol. 162, No. 30

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House began consideration of H.R. 2406, to protect and enhance opportunities for recreational hunting, fishing, and shooting. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, February 26th.<P/>H. Res. 619, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2406) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 241 yeas to 175 nays, Roll No. 91, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 240 yeas to 178 nays, Roll No. 90.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House began consideration of H.R. 2406, to protect and enhance opportunities for recreational hunting, fishing, and shooting. Consideration is expected to resume tomorrow, February 26th.<P/>H. Res. 619, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2406) was agreed to by a yea-and-nay vote of 241 yeas to 175 nays, Roll No. 91, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 240 yeas to 178 nays, Roll No. 90.
